Award.AwardTitle: EarthCube IA: Collaborative Proposal: Interdisciplinary Earth Data Alliance as a Model for Integrating Earthcube Technology Resources and Engaging the Broad Community
Award.AbstractNarration:
A fundamental requirement for EarthCube is access to a comprehensive spectrum of well-curated, reliably re-usable, and seamlessly interoperable scientific data, but this does not exist today with many Geoscience domains still lacking sustainable data services. This project is a collaboration between an established data facility in the solid Earth sciences, IEDA (Interdisciplinary Earth Data Alliance), three scientifically related data communities in the solid Earth sciences that lack data facilities (deep seafloor processes, mineral physics, polar cryosphere), a research data collection (MetPetDB), a group of computer scientists that specialize in distributed information systems and interoperability, and a social scientist to re-structure the IEDA data facility, both organizationally and architecturally, to create the pilot of a multi-institutional and multi-disciplinary alliance of data providers. The goal is to create a model for other data facilities to partner with so far ?underserved? data communities to broaden integration of Geoscience domains into EarthCube, and advance both interdisciplinary and discipline-specific data science, while realizing economies of scale by sharing common data services.

Using IEDA as a testbed, the project will adopt elements of three EarthCube technologies that have been or are being developed by EarthCube Building Block projects: CINERGI (Community INventory of EarthCube Resources for Geoscience Interoperability), GeoWS (Geoscience Web Services), and GeoLink (Semantic Web technology), to build the architecture of the alliance, thereby testing, validating, and potentially improving these technologies. The technical work will focus on creating a flexible and scalable framework that will allow a growing number of partner systems to plug into shared capabilities such as applications for integrated data discovery and data submission and contribute their resources. Architectural changes at IEDA will go hand-in-hand with the transition of IEDA?s organizational structure toward the envisioned multi-institutional alliance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Development of centralized data management infrastructure for multiple data repositories is important in geosciences and in other domains because individually small data facilities often are not capable of creating and maintaining data management, submission, indexing, discovery, publication, and data re-use infrastructure components, at the same time staying on top of the latest technology trends. The ATP project has proposed an overall architectural technical design and organizational structure, and developed respective charters and several prototype data management components leading to such a unified system. Besides contributing to the overall ATP system design, the UCSD partner in this collaborative project focused on centralized cross-repository data discovery. The data discovery prototype integrating metadata from several partners of the Integrated Earth Data Alliance (IEDA) is one of the key deliverables of the project; it was released to the community in 2018. The system lets researchers interested in solid earth sciences perform dataset search across IEDA partners using text search, map navigation, and by search facets. The search facets are specifically constructed to reflect common characteristics expected by geoscientists as they narrow down the discovered set of records to find the resources they need. For developers, the data discovery system provides standard API access to records using semantically and structurally unified metadata descriptions. The search interface is built using ESRI Geoportal and ElasticSearch. It leverages the experience of cross-disciplinary portal developed within the EarthCube Data Discovery Studio (DDS) project, a system primarily being developed by the UCSD partner in this project. The DDS project provides access to 1.4 million metadata records from 40+ geoscience repositories, which are semantically enhanced using an automated metadata augmentation pipeline developed by the EarthCube CINERGI ("Community Inventory of Earthcube Resources for Geoscience Interoperability") project. This project developed the technology for automatic generation of search facets based on enhanced metadata. The DDS prototype, in addition to search, lets users work with metadata records across repositories: contribute resource descriptions, manually edit the metadata, trace metadata provenance, invoke workbench functionality by passing document IDs to a prototype research workbench (a collection of Jupyter notebooks), and export metadata for indexing by other data search engines such as the Google Dataset Search. The IEDA Data Discovery Portal developed by this project implemented advanced search solutions from the DDS and related projects, and presents a prototype that can be reused in other disciplinary contexts within and beyond the geosciences.
